Answer: The basic principle —currency in standardized physical (and now, sometimes digital) units of reliable designated relative purchasing power, which can be exchanged among traders in return for a range of goods and services— hasn’t changed. Currency “velocity” has changed with tech advances enabling faster moves among users, from “cash” to checks to digital. Future changes will mirror historical ones, political moves to (most frequently) reduce unit purchasing power via deliberate inflation, increasingly easy to do as physical standards like gold and commodities have been abandoned by governmentsThe basic principle —currency in standardized physical (and now, sometimes digital) units of reliable designated relative purchasing power, which can be exchanged among traders in return for a range of goods and services— hasn’t changed. Currency “velocity” has changed with tech advances enabling faster moves among users, from “cash” to checks to digital. Future changes will mirror historical ones, political moves to (most frequently) reduce unit purchasing power via deliberate inflation, increasingly easy to do as physical standards like gold and commodities have been abandoned by governments eager to reduce their own costs of promised debt repayment using the same number of intentionally less-valuable units. What kings once did by ordering that coins contain more cheaper metals and less gold, politicians now do via their central banks’ issuance of additional currency to go into circulation irrespective of no similar or equal additions to underlying economic-activity intensity, thereby intentionally reducing the purchasing power value of existing in-circulation units. It goes under such new labels as Keynesian stimulation and quantitative easing.Martin Harris

Answer: This will draw ire from many, I suppose, but I think the major event that delayed technological advancement was the advent of Christianity. Rome and China were the two most advanced civilisations technologically in the world 2000 years ago, and with the fall of Rome and the rise of Christianity (two events I think are linked) Europe was plunged into the dark ages. Why were they dark? Not because “barbarians” were less sophisticated than Romans (nearly all the “barbarian” leaders had been pretty well assimilated into Roman culture anyway) but because Christianity squashed inquest. The church loThis will draw ire from many, I suppose, but I think the major event that delayed technological advancement was the advent of Christianity. Rome and China were the two most advanced civilisations technologically in the world 2000 years ago, and with the fall of Rome and the rise of Christianity (two events I think are linked) Europe was plunged into the dark ages. Why were they dark? Not because “barbarians” were less sophisticated than Romans (nearly all the “barbarian” leaders had been pretty well assimilated into Roman culture anyway) but because Christianity squashed inquest. The church looked down upon people learning to read out of fear that they be drawn into heresy, and the underlying tenet of christianity was that everything that is, is because of god… no reason to look into it, just shut up and pray… and pay your tithes.I know that there are many revisionist historians who say that the dark ages weren’t really dark, etc. but just look at the history. I mean the amount of written history. Any scholar of Rome can easily check the name of every single Roman magistrate from the fall of Tarquin the Proud to the fall of Rome itself, and then there are centuries during which we don’t even know if many of the kings were mythical or not (Arthur?), centuries in which not one major advance was made, no philosophical works of any note were penned unless they were religious, and therefore introspective in nature. Debate became theological debate only. The renaissance reallyI honestly think that if Rome hadn’t fallen and the church had not stuck its holy nose in the affairs of humans then we could have walked on the moon in 1600.

Originally a barter system but this is of no use if the other party has nothing you are currently interested in! Thus the need for tokens considered to be equal to the objects or items wanted by the other party. Thus the need for tokens considered to be equal to the objects or items wanted by the other party. Shells, glass beads, pearls, gold, silver, precious jewels you name it has been used down the centuries.When actual stamped previous metal coins came into common use it was customary for small pieces to be nibbled off in a an attempt to defraud the vendor. Merchants started to weigh them to make sure coins had not been tampered with. Later coins had fancy edges formed to prevent “nibbling”.

Different populations with different diets are also developing slightly different digestive enzymes.But even in a state of nature humans evolve only slowly, because we have a long generation time, a small number of offspring and a limited number of partners, and nowadays we’ve slowed down even more because our technology insulates us against many selection pressures.

Answer: No, for a very interesting reason.You see, animals evolve within the sphere of their kingdom (mineral kingdom, plant kingdom, have different rules for evolution, specific to each kingdom). The purpose of animal evolution is survival - of individual animal with fight-or-flight mechanism among others - and of species it belongs to - mating. Animals change in order to survive different conditions and circumstances of their ecological niche. Sometimes they move to a different niche. Sometimes they swing between conditions - like a certain iguana in Galapagos that grows longer limbs and becomes ablNo, for a very interesting reason.You see, animals evolve within the sphere of their kingdom (mineral kingdom, plant kingdom, have different rules for evolution, specific to each kingdom). The purpose of animal evolution is survival - of individual animal with fight-or-flight mechanism among others - and of species it belongs to - mating. Animals change in order to survive different conditions and circumstances of their ecological niche. Sometimes they move to a different niche. Sometimes they swing between conditions - like a certain iguana in Galapagos that grows longer limbs and becomes able to clime trees and shrubs in times of drought, while in times of normal rains it looses this ability and manage to eat the abundant grass.Humans are a kingdom of itself. Even if they have all the animal features, they have the abstract thinking, separating them from the animal kingdom. Humor, science, art, all these products of human intelligence, cannot be found in animal life. This is why humans have psychology while animals have ethology. See the differences between these two sciences and you will see why and how the two kingdoms are separated by the gap of different thinking.Therefore evolution for humans unfolds in a completely different sphere - that of society. Maybe at a certain geological time man and apes looked the same. But the way they evolved is totally different: the apes kept their ecological niche as long as it was possible, while humans evolved firstly physically, and finally using the upright locomotion, bipedal one, they spread all over the Earth, regardless of any ecological niche - even more, they did it in all manners possible: some - like the Eskimo and the nomads, became meat eaters, while others, from social reasons, became vegetarians. Some animals suffered the same change, but humans are able to switch during their life, not during ages!So human evolution is permanent - but social, not animal like. We still fight each other, when we should be cooperating, split due to religious, ethnic, ideological or whatever reasons. We still are able to totally annihilate life on Earth - and not only by nukes - pollution and destruction of natural spaces may bring another era of mass extinction, and not due to natural factors.Will we change our old, outdated ways of living, or we shall turn Earth into a desert? Because we are so resourceful that we may outlive all the rest of animal and plant kingdoms, with the exception of those species we consider ”useful”. Do you know that 2000 years ago men use to eat close to 1400 species of plants/tree/shrubs/mushrooms all year around, while today only 20 species are part of our food list? Just pay attention to what you eat, and you will discover that the staple list is extremely small: rice, wheat, potato, corn, with some addition of other vegetables like tomato, peppers, and so on. The extended list may grow to 200 species, but is still far from the 1400. Of course the reason was that the resources were then far scarcer that today.So we keep evolving, but not in animal, physical way, but human, social one.

Answer: You'll need to define "meaningful technology." It would seem to me that meaningful technology predates Homo sapiens sapiens. Our not-quite-human ancestors were already using fire, something no other species (well, genus anyway) has ever done, and we were making unprecedented use of stone tools. Throw in use of perishable materials like fibers, leather, and wood to make tools and garments, and we were able to spread out from Africa and the Middle East to colonizeYou'll need to define "meaningful technology." Answer: Big data is impacting every business, starting from small companies to Fortune 500 enterprises all are revolving around the BIG data! What actually is this big data? Big data is an evolving term that describes any voluminous amount of structured, semi-structured and unstructured data that has the potential to be mined for information. And here are the 4 V’s by which big data is been characterized –• VOLUME – Scale of data• VELOCITY – Analysis of streaming data• VARIETY – the Different form of data• VERACITY – Uncertainty of dataThe company size is not the factor to consider big data. Big dataBig data is impacting every business, starting from small companies to Fortune 500 enterprises all are revolving around the BIG data! What actually is this big data? Big data is an evolving term that describes any voluminous amount of structured, semi-structured and unstructured data that has the potential to be mined for information. And here are the 4 V’s by which big data is been characterized –• VOLUME – Scale of data• VELOCITY – Analysis of streaming data• VARIETY – the Different form of data• VERACITY – Uncertainty of dataThe company size is not the factor to consider big data. Big data technology can help you if you have a website, an active social media presence, if you accept credit/debit card payments, or uses data collection form for customers. And analyzing these data can help you to improve your customer experience and in turn, increase your business ROI.Now, are you thinking how big data is helping companies to provide a customized user experience? Big data can actually help in collecting better marketing data about the customer, this gives companies a better idea of what the customer wants, how they will use, and which channels/platforms they typically choose to buy a product or service.While companies are continuously seeking new opportunities to benefit from data collection, but when a user hears these things he/she will definitely get worried, because it’s a matter of personal data and privacy. So in order to gain customers, trust companies should build and maintain a privacy policy and the systems/security needed to protect customer data.Now let’s have a look at how big data is changing business –1. Advanced Business IntelligenceBefore the rise of big data, business intelligence was rather limited. Integrating advanced analytics for big data with BI systems is an important step toward gaining a full return on investment. Now many companies are gearing up by hiring business intelligence experts because they help take a company to the next level.2. Personalized MarketingBig data analysis can help business predict what products customers might need in the future. Imagine how your business would benefit from being able to market the products that you knew your customers needed and knew enough information about them to customize for specific needs.3. Proactive Customer ServiceWith big data, businesses can know exactly what their customers need before the customer raises the query. This kind of proactive customer service will revolutionize business that desires to differentiate themselves based on their customer service. Big data analysis can also help customer support team to proactively contact customers on accounts where predictive analysis determines the customers might have made a purchase decision but in future, they can be a potential customer.4. Customer Responsive ProductsBig data promises to not only improve customer service but also allows companies to make customer responsive products. Product design can help in fulfilling the needs of customers in ways that have never been possible. Instead of customers telling you what they are looking for in a product, you can use data analysis to predict what they are looking for in a product. Even this can help in creating a better picture of what a future product should look like.5. Improving Business EfficiencyBig data is supplying rich data about every product and process. These data’s are helping smart businesses to conquer the marketplace. Engineers are analyzing big data and looking for ways to make processes run more efficiently. When constraints are discovered and removed, the business performance increases.6. Cost ReductionCompanies are now using big data to accurately find trends and predict future events within their respective industries. Knowing when something might happen can improve forecasts and planning. Planners can determine when to produce and how much to produce. They can even determine how much inventory to keep in hand.According to estimates, it is revealed that the global market share of big data and its allied technology is expected to reach approximately $57 billion by the year 2020, generating a need for over 50,000 skilled Big Data experts and data scientists. The US is the forerunner in the generation, consumption and deployment of data and this technology. Thus the big data is connecting and building the digital future.

Answer: When life began there were no brains. So the brain has evolved essentially out of nothing.Even single-celled organisms have some intelligence, including the ability to find and steer towards food, and in some cases primitive memory. These behaviors are implemented via biochemical pathways, since only multi-cellular organisms have a nervous system.Worms have a very primitive brain.Figure: Worm nervous systemInsects have nervous systems but also onlyWhen life began there were no brains. So the brain has evolved essentially out of nothing.Even single-celled organisms have some intelligence, including the ability to find and steer towards food, and in some cases primitive memory. These behaviors are implemented via biochemical pathways, since only multi-cellular organisms have a nervous system.Worms have a very primitive brain.Figure: Worm nervous systemInsects have nervous systems but also only barely have a brain. What they have instead are numerous bulges throughout their nervous system called "ganglia" that are information processing hubs serving the basic survival needs of the animal. Insects have a complex network of ganglia in their head, since this is where most of the sensory organs are located (eyes, antennae for smell, feelers, mouth), and this ganglia complex is something of a proto-brain.Figure: Insect nervous systemFish have very basic brains in their head. Brains get steadily larger and more complex as evolution proceeds through reptiles, birds, and mammals.The brains of birds have been studied extensively because the song-learning process is believed to parallel language learning in humans. The general architecture of the "avian brain" (neuroscientists avoid the somewhat insulting term "bird brain") is almost unrecognizable compared to a human brain, and yet the evolution of various components into those of the human brain has been traced and "homologous mappings" have been worked out.Figure: Brain of song bird (avian brain).Figure: Human BrainThe brain of each species is optimized for the unique needs of that species. Mice have a special brain area for spatial mapping using their whiskers (the "barrel cortex"); bats have a specialized brain area for echolocation (vision using sound echoes); and birds have several specialized regions for song-learning. In humans, up to 2/3 of the brain is involved in vision in some way, whereas certain rodents that live permanently underground have practically no visual brain region at all. Dogs have an unusually large olfactory brain area to help with their keen sense of smell, while cats which need to hunt have the most advanced visual brain network second only to primates.Unfortunately, scientists don'tRelated:

Answer: Understanding the brain is key to living a good life, once you know how you and other people operate you are better equipped to deal with life.This is going to be a long read, grab your favourite beverage and sit comfortably :)Now let’s imagine our brain as a car.This car has 4 drivers.Only one driver can drive the car at a time while other drivers can influence the driving.At any point, any of the 4 drivers can pick up the steering wheel and start driving the car.Meet your 4 drivers:## SurvivalYour survival driver is responsible for 3 key tasks:Understanding the brain is key to living a good life, once you know how you and other people operate you are better equipped to deal with life.This is going to be a long read, grab your favourite beverage and sit comfortably :)Now let’s imagine our brain as a car.This car has 4 drivers.Only one driver can drive the car at a time while other drivers can influence the driving.At any point, any of the 4 drivers can pick up the steering wheel and start driving the car.Meet your 4 drivers:## SurvivalYour survival driver is responsible for 3 key tasks:Survival driver is activated in life threatening situations (ex: car about to hit you) and in modern times, stress can activate it; then what we have is:What does this mean?When you see someone who gets angry easily or anxious or feeling down, their survival brain is now driving them.There is no use trying to reason with people being driven by their survival brain, everything is a threat to them at that point.We need to bring the person out of the survival:Your survival driver usually needs to go through logic before activating but if it gets activated often (ex: constant stress from work) then it's constantly active.At this point the person affected will easily get aggressive, anxious or helpless without a real threat.The solution to this is to calm down your survival driver by constant meditation and being in a soothing environment - do not use drugs to calm yourself down as that will only make things worse in the long run.## TrustYour trust driver is interesting because it defines your position within a social group and works on 2 main areas within 4 axis:Areas:Axis:X axis for self confidence (trust in yourself) and Y axis for trust in othersYou want to be in the centre - assertive, confident and not worried about your actions.We usually shift around the graph depending on where we are and who we are with.Each axis has 5 levels or stages we go through, 1 being the first and least hurtful stage and 5 being the last and worst.Levels 1–3 are treatable by yourself or with a close friend or family, if you reach levels 4-5 then it’s recommended you seek professional help.When you haveWhen things go well for the dominant, they believe it’s their doing.When things go wrong, it’s someone elses fault.If you know anyone that acts super charming and nice to people while they use them as a utility to obtain what they want, they have reached the top of dominance and need help.When you haveWhen things go well for the submissive, they believe they got lucky.When things go wrong, they believe it’s their fault.If you know anyone that cuts themselves, they have reached the bottom of self confidence and need help - extreme submissiveness will lead to depression and suicide.Now we will talk about going left/right in the trust in others axis.If you haveIn extreme case, the person gets used by people regularly and needs help.If you haveIn an extreme case, this turns into paranoia and the person needs help.Some things to note about the trust driver:## MotivationYour motivation driver stores your deepest motivations and raw emotions as well as your memories (the good, the bad and the ugly)Most of the time motivation driver is what’s driving you around by running on autopilot by recognising situations you have been in and uses the standard operating procedure you teach it.Your motivation driver knows everything you have ever learnt!This driver is super efficient because it uses the minimum attention span to carry out tasks, allowing us to do more than 2 things at once.For example when you are driving a car and talking to your friend passenger at the same time, your motivation driver is in control.This driver has 3 layers of motivation:This is why some things you do gives you energy and makes you happy even if you are not exactly good at it (ex: drawing) because it’s an intrinsic motivation of yours.This is also why some people can get extremely good at certain things (ex: drawing) since it’s an intrinsic motivation that keeps them happy and working on until they master it.The sweet spot is finding your intrinsic motivations and making a career out of it, then you are getting paid to do what you truly love to do and which actually makes you happy.2. Extrinsic:Everything that influences your decision and opinion is stored here (ex: why do you like certain music, food or fashion)The interesting part is this motivation usually does not last more than 3–6 months.3. Obsessions:This stores your passions but also your addictions such as being a workaholic, drugs, shopaholic and chasing stuff.When it’s on, you are not free to choose what you want anymore and will go after the obsession.# Imagination:This is the marvel of evolution, it’s what makes us human.Your imagination driver gives you creativity and adaptation.It should take control when dealing with new and complex situations that require you to think out of the box.People usually don’t let imagination driver take control and stick to their motivation driver instead, which leads them to lose out on big innovations.Examples:These mistakes happened because the people in charge relied on their motivation driver which only thinks from what it already knows - if they had used their imagination driver, they can see a future that Steve Jobs saw.When your imagination driver is taking control, you feel calm and in full control.How to activate it on command? think for yourself these questions:Making yourself answer these questions in your head activates the imagination driver.In conclusion we can say that even though our brain is too complex to summarise in a Quora post, this framework gives us a better idea on how we go about our daily lives and how we can use this knowledge to live a better life.Hope this helps you as much as it helped me.I might be updating this post with more findings, follow it if you want to keep updated.All the best!
